name: spinacia-oleracea
definition: Spinach  is a leafy green flowering plant native to central and western Asia.
description:
Spinach is a leafy herbaceous annual plant grown for its leaves which are used as a vegetable.

The spinach plant has simple leaves which stem from the center of the plant and measure about 2 to 30 centimeters long and 1 to 15 centimeters across.

The leaves grow in a rosette and can appear crinkled or flat, with larger leaves at the base of the plant and small leaves higher on the flowering stem.

The plant produces small yellow-green flowers which are 3 to 4 millimeters in diameter.

The flowers produce small, hard, dry, lumpy fruit clusters, 5 to 10 millimeters across, containing several seeds.

Spinach is an annual and survives only one growing season and can reach 30 centimeters in height.

Spinach leaves are a common edible vegetable consumed either fresh, or after storage using preservation techniques by canning, freezing, or dehydration.

Spinach has low caloric value and high content of various vitamins and minerals which act beneficially on the human health.

It may be eaten cooked or raw, and the taste differs considerably; the high oxalate content may be reduced by steaming.

As a medicine, spinach is used to treat stomach and intestinal complaints and fatigue.

It is also used as a blood-builder and an appetite stimulant.

Spinach grows well in cool areas and can survive the first frost of temperate climates.

It will germinates and grows optimally at temperatures between 4 and 16°C but can withstand temperatures as low as -7°C.

Spinach grows best in a well draining loamy soil.

The soil temperature should not exceed 21°C.

Spinach is propagated from seed usually being sown in early spring, for a summer harvest, or sown in fall for harvest in winter and spring.

Seeds should be planted at a depth of one to two centimeters leaving 33 to 38 centimeters between rows.

When seedlings reach about 5 centimeters in height they should be thinned out to a spacing of 8 to 10 centimeters between plants.

In 2017, world production of spinach was 27.9 million tonnes, with China alone accounting for 92% of the total.

Spinach is thought to have originated about 2000 years ago in ancient Persia (now Iran).

It was introduced to India and ancient China via Nepal in 647 BC.

Due to its origin, spinach is known as Persian Green in China.

It was brought to Europe in 12th century where it instantly gained popularity.

contextual.caption: Spinach does best when growing in moist, nitrogen-rich soil. Spinach plants form a deep taproot; for best growth, loosen the soil at least 30 centimeters deep before planting.

featured.caption:
Baby is a variety of spinach with flat, spade-shaped leaves that are soft and tender in texture.

Baby spinach is so clean and mild in flavor that the leaves and stems can be eaten raw.

facts.name: There are three groups of spinach
facts.value: All varieties of spinach can be divided in three groups based on the texture, size and shape of leaves. Savoy spinach has dark green and curly leaves. Flat-leaf spinach has broad and smooth leaves. Semi-savoy has partially crinkled leaves.

facts.name: Is diuretic and laxative
facts.value: Spinach facilitates removal of the excess water from the body (acts like diuretic) and emptying of bowels (acts like laxative).

facts.name: Greatest manufacturer in the world
facts.value: China is the greatest manufacturer of spinach in the world. It produces nearly 19 million tons or 95% of globally consumed spinach.

facts.name: Pigments were used in painting
facts.value: Green pigments extracted from spinach were used in painting during the medieval times.

facts.name: Spinach is a annual plant
facts.value: Spinach belongs to the group of annual plants, which mean that it completes its life cycle in one year.

facts.name: May cause kidney stones
facts.value: Some people may develop kidney stones after consumption of spinach due to high content of oxalic acid that can be found in this plant.

facts.name: Can reach 30 centimeters
facts.value: Spinach has thin, flexible stem that can reach 30 centimeters in height.

facts.name: Spinach is a source of power
facts.value: Popeye is a cartoon character which uses spinach as a source of power. Thanks to this cartoon, popularity and consumption of spinach increased for 30% during the 1930’s in the USA.

facts.name: Prevent excessive bleeding
facts.value: French soldiers consumed wine mixed with spinach juice during the First World War to recuperate from excessive bleeding.

facts.name: Small yellow-green flowers
facts.value: Spinach develops small yellow-green flowers. Each plant produces either male (stamens) or female (pistil) reproductive organs (dioecious plant). Flowers are pollinated by wind.

facts.name: Excellent source of vitamins
facts.value: Spinach is excellent source of vitamin A, K, E, C and vitamins of the B group. It is also rich source of manganese, magnesium, calcium and iron.

facts.name: Should be consumed fresh
facts.value: Spinach should be consumed while it is still fresh because it easily loses vitamins and minerals and becomes limp after few days. Prolonged cooking also drastically reduces vitamin content.

facts.name: Spinach can be consumed raw
facts.value: Spinach can be consumed raw (in the form of salads) or boiled. It is used for the preparation of numerous salty meals.

facts.name: Produce fruits with seeds
facts.value: Spinach produces dry, lumpy fruit gathered in clusters that contain few seeds.

facts.name: Leaves are the edible part
facts.value: Leaves are edible part of spinach. They are oval in shape and alternately arranged on the stem. Biggest leaves are located on the base, and smallest on the top of the plant.

related.definition: Beetroot is one of the several cultivated varieties of beets family, grown for their edible taproots and their leaves.
Lettuce  is an annual plant of the daisy family grown as a leaf vegetable, but sometimes for its stem and seeds.

links.description: Data, maps and articles about spinach.
